author: .vbuterin
content: Totally random exploration question: would we have been better off if the EVM was a higher level language? Say, make the EVM something similar to LLL

author: .vbuterin
content: Right now, compilers feel complex in a lot of ways, and a lot of that is because the EVM is "close to the metal". But in reality there's no good reason for the EVM to be close to the metal

author: .vbuterin
content: eg. right now we have *two* ways to make calls: calls that get compiled into jumps, and calls that are calls

author: .vbuterin
content: A from-scratch higher-level EVM might not have bytes memory, but it would have a built-in concept of variables, calls, conditionals, loops...

author: tersec
content: There's a risk it'd have been a less versatile compiler target, would have over-determined the nature of (yet higher level) languages which might plausibly target it.

author: .vbuterin
content: What kind of languages might have been deterred by this kind of EVM?

author: .vbuterin
content: I feel like Move-like langs would be about as easy as today, maybe even easier

author: .vbuterin
content: I guess "existing langs" (eg. Rust) compiling to EVM would be harder

author: .vbuterin
content: Although.... WASM is a higher-level VM, and lots of langs compile to WASM just fine!
